Name: FISH TRAP
Elicitation_Notes: dibuat dari bambu untuk menangkap ikan yang ditinggal. NOT fish net or fish line.

Name: WALK
Comment: Some word lists may contain elicitations for ‘jalan (kaki)’

Name: GECKO
Elicitation_Notes: A type of lizard that makes a ‘toke’ sound

Name: EUCALYPT
Elicitation_Notes: Specifically, that type of tree, not any white wood. Try to probe deeper if a calque of “white tree” is given first.

Name: KING
Comment: High overlap with ‘chieftain’

Name: RACK (FOR STORING FOOD)
Elicitation_Notes: There may be two types, a high one (for e.g. storage) and a lower one; if so, elicit both.

Name: DROP (SOMETHING)
Elicitation_Notes: menjatuhkan

Name: RETURN HOME
Comment: from Keraf

Name: SQUAT
Elicitation_Notes: To crouch as on an Indonesian toilet, NOT: to kneel

Name: MILLET
Elicitation_Notes: If you can, show a picture.
Comment: Some word lists may contain elicitations for ‘botok’

Name: CURSE
Elicitation_Notes: Please elicit the verb

Name: WHERE
Comment: Keraf: ‘di mana’; Some lists also include "ke/dari mana", "to/from where"

Name: AT
Comment: Keraf: ‘di’

Name: INSIDE
Comment: Keraf: ‘dalam’; Other collectors may have elicited ‘dalam’, which on its own means ‘deep’.

Name: RIB
Elicitation_Notes: In South Sulawesi: iga

Name: RICE EAR BUG
Elicitation_Notes: Destroys rice crops and gives off a bad smell when disturbed.
Comment: Leptocorisa oratoria

Name: FOOTPRINT
Comment: from Keraf

Name: SLAP
Elicitation_Notes: Mimic the movement, we look for the painful one
Comment: There may be confusion corcerning this concept and ‘to clap’. Other elicitations were ‘tampar’, ‘menampar’.

Name: ROAD
Elicitation_Notes: Please ensure to elicit the noun

Name: DAWN
Elicitation_Notes: Elicit time of day, not prayer – ‘fajar’ may be helpful in some regions

Name: TURTLE
Comment: Some forms connected to this concept may have been elicited using the confusing ‘kura-kura laut’ (‘sea tortoise’). Those forms are marked in the word lists.

Name: MOUND OF STONES FOR RITUAL ACTIVITIES
Description: A mound of stones or altar around/on which ritual activities are held.
English: mound of stones for ritual activities
Elicitation_Notes: The cultural features questionnaire also asks for this term.

Name: CANOE
Comment: Some word lists contain elicitations for ‘sampan’ (which is a small boat with sail)

Name: HOUSE
Description: A dwelling built in a vernacular or ethnic architectural style.
Comment: Different forms in the counterparts for this concept may imply different architectural styles. The concepticon concept is more general.

Name: COOKED CORN
Elicitation_Notes: Refers to a specific type of corn porridge which may not exist in all areas

Name: PENIS
Elicitation_Notes: Often taboo. Be sensitive, explain: ini sehingga anggota tubuh semua  bisa dimasukkan dalam dalam kamus, itu saja, jangan marah bapak? If they still remain silent, skip.

Name: LONG
Comment: Keraf: ‘panjang’

Name: GEBANG PALM
Elicitation_Notes: If the word "gebang" is not recognized, try "g(e)wang"
Comment: Corypha utan (‘gebang palm’ or ‘cabbage palm’)

Name: SARONG
Description: The female style of a large tube or length of fabric, often wrapped around the waist, worn throughout much of South Asia.
Elicitation_Notes: If there are different words for male and female sarongs, collect the female one.
Comment: Concepticon has the more general concept SARONG 2413 (either male or female)

Name: GRAIN
Elicitation_Notes: There might not be a general term. If there isn’t, leave it empty.

Name: NARROW
Elicitation_Notes: Not: rumah sempit (crowded/small house), or pakaian sempit (clothes that are too tight).

Name: WOOD
Comment: Some word lists may contain elicitations for ‘kayu pohon’

Name: THOU
Elicitation_Notes: Specifically, the singular one.

Name: LOUSE
English: louse in hair; head louse; mother louse
Comment: Keraf: ‘kutu’

Name: PLANT STEM
Comment: from Keraf

Name: FALL
Comment: Keraf: ‘jatuh’ – There are usually many ways of saying this

Name: FOWL
Elicitation_Notes: There might not be a term like this, between bird and chicken. If there isn’t, leave it empty.

Name: OVEN
Comment: Threestone hearth, in particular

Name: INITIATION CEREMONY
Elicitation_Notes: Please specify which type of ceremony(s) is given
Comment: May refer to a different ceremony in different cultures

Name: WAKE UP (SOMEONE)
Elicitation_Notes: Like 'membangunkan' (but not with the sense of 'to erect a building')
DO NOT ELICIT THIS, this is a legacy concept covered elsewhere
Comment: from Keraf – we don’t actually know which one he elicited

Name: TINEA
Comment: The overlap with ‘ringworm’ is high, both are types of dermaphytosis, yet from the sampled lexicon they appear as two consistent, distinct concepts.

Name: CONJUNCTIVITIS
Elicitation_Notes: Ketika mata pedih dan merah kemudian ketika bangun tidur mata sulit dibuka dan kadang-kadang keluar cairan kuning.
Comment: Some word lists contain elicitations for ‘mata merah’, some for ‘belek’

Name: ORDER
Comment: Some word lists may contain elicitations for ‘perintah’, which may also be a noun instead of a verb.

Name: PLANT RICE
Description: put a (rice) seedling in the flooded ground of a paddy field so that it strikes root and grows.
Comment: Concepticon has the more general concept PLANT (SOMETHING) 1486 (not specific to the type of planting done for rice)

Name: SHARP
Elicitation_Notes: Of spear (tombak) or machete (parang); if there are two different words, elicit both.

Name: OTHER
Comment: from Keraf

Name: SOME
Comment: from Keraf

Name: FOG
Elicitation_Notes: kabut = fog, NOT embun = air yang menetes dari daun di pagi hari

Name: OLD (AGED)
Comment: Keraf: ‘tua’

Name: ASH
Elicitation_Notes: NOT 'debu' (dust, after you have been sweeping)
Comment: Keraf: ‘abu’

Name: PLANT YAM
Description: put a (yam) seed tuber into ridged-up ground so that it strikes root and grows.
Comment: Concepticon has the more general concept PLANT (SOMETHING) 1486 (not specific to the type of planting done for yam)

Name: FEVER
Comment: If the language has a clear class of adjectives, older wordlists may have the concept ‘feverish’ here instead.

Name: DOWN OR BELOW
Elicitation_Notes: If there are different words for the place and the direction, elicit both and annotate.

Name: HERE
Elicitation_Notes: If there is confusion, ask for ‘di sini’

Name: LOOK FOR
Comment: Related: HUNT 1435

Name: LOOM
Elicitation_Notes: Kata untuk seluru alat menenun. Tetapi di sini alat tenun tidak ada nama umum, dan masing-masing bagian ada namanya. (It is likely that there is no word referring to a loom as such,  only words referring to parts of it. If you can make a picture of a loom, you could try to elicit the words for the various parts. If this is not possible, just skip this.)

Name: DEW
Comment: from Keraf

Name: FATHER'S SISTER
Indonesian: bibi; ayah punya saudara perempuan; tante

Name: BURDEN STICK
Elicitation_Notes: Tongkat untuk bawa sesuatu di bahu

Name: BARN OR SHED
Comment: In some parts of the region, ‘gudang’ is not a separate building, just a separate room.

Name: FIST
Comment: from Keraf

Name: SPINE
Elicitation_Notes: Or try ‘tulang belakang’

Name: NO OR NOT
Elicitation_Notes: Negation of verbal/adjectival predicate, e.g. Saya tidak suka minum bir; Saya tidak sakit. (Not 'bukan').

Name: WIFE
Elicitation_Notes: Not 'married woman'

Name: DIGGING STICK
Elicitation_Notes: NOT: ‘linggis’=‘crowbar’
Comment: Some word lists may have elicted ‘alat sedot tanah’

Name: THATCH
English: thatch; reed or grass used for making roofs

Name: RITUAL GROUND
English: ground for ritual activities and public meetings
Elicitation_Notes: The cultural features questionnaire also asks for this term.

Name: VEIN
Elicitation_Notes: NOT ‘urat daging’/‘tendon’, or any other string in the body
Comment: Due to confusion with the indonesian word, some word lists may confuse this concept with ‘tendon’/‘urat (daging)’ or other stringy components of a body.

Name: SOLE (FOOT)
Elicitation_Notes: Or ‘telapak’

Name: CORRECT (RIGHT)
Comment: Keraf: ‘betul’

Name: BELLY OR STOMACH
Comment: Includes the forms in Keraf (1978) for ‘isi perut’.

Name: UNHUSKED RICE
Elicitation_Notes: If there is a distinction between unhusked rice still on the harvested plant and rice corns in the husks, but removed from the grain head, take the one for the first meaning.

Name: PAINFUL OR SICK
Elicitation_Notes: There may be several words, e.g. sakit setelah dipukul (pain felt after being hit); sakit luka (pain of a wound), or sakit demam (have a fever). We look for the word used for sakit demam.

Name: RINGWORM
Comment: The overlap with ‘tinea’ is high, both are types of dermaphytosis, yet from the sampled lexicon they appear as two consistent, distinct concepts.

Name: BURN (SOMETHING)
Comment: Keraf: ‘membakar’

Name: MOTHER'S BROTHER
Indonesian: paman; ibu py saudara laki-laki; om

Name: ROTTEN
Elicitation_Notes: NOT ‘smelly’ if there are different words for both.

Name: BATHE (SOMEONE)
Comment: Concepticon has the related concept BATHE 138 (which is A=P, here we have A≠P)

Name: UP OR ABOVE
Elicitation_Notes: If there are different words for the place and the direction, elicit both and annotate.

Name: FLOWER
Comment: Keraf: ‘flower’

Name: PERSON
Elicitation_Notes: Not 'manusia' (human being). Elicit 'orang' with a numeral, for example 'ada satu orang, dua orang, tiga orang...'

Name: VAGINA
Elicitation_Notes: Often taboo. Be sensitive, explain: ini sehingga anggota tubuh semua  bisa dimasukkan dalam dalam kamus, itu saja, jangan marah bapak? If they still remain silent, skip.

Name: WHEN
Comment: Keraf: ‘bilamana’

Name: SHORT
Elicitation_Notes: If the word for ‘short stick’ and ‘short man’ differ, elicit both. Do not elicit ‘short time’.
Comment: Keraf: ‘pendek’

Name: ANIMAL
Elicitation_Notes: If they ask which animals, say 'kata untuk .... seperti sapi, ayam, kambing.' (If they also have a different word for animals that are not eaten, e.g. rats (tikus) or snakes (ular), then that is NOT the word we look for.)
